name: noname
text: In this video i'm going to describe how the text to speech add on works

name: noname
text: Firstly, we need to install the add on

name: noname
text: If you're using Windows, you will need to right click blender and click run as administrator for the first time
On Linux and Mac just open Blender as per usual

name: noname
text: We can install the add on by opening the preferences in Blender, and installing the Text to Speech zip file from the add on menu

name: noname
text: It might take a moment to install the text to speech library

name: noname
text: In linux you also need to open a terminal and copy paste the following command

name: noname
text: The command can be found in the video description

name: noname
text: When you navigate to the video editing interface you should see the Text to Speech tab

name: noname
text: If it doesn't appear, you can toggle the system console to see any errors in Windows

name: noname
text: In linux and mac you need to open Blender from a terminal to see any errors

name: noname
text: You can make individual audio strips by typing something in the text field and pressing Text to Speech

name: noname
text: Alternatively you can import a closed caption file and it will convert all the strips to audio

name: noname
text: Currently text, csv, srt and sbv files are supported
voice
pitch
and rate
can be chosen before converting text to speech
You can edit captions, move them around and add new ones
caption data is saved to the blendfile

name: noname
text: You can then export closed caption files and it will export an updated file that corresponds to your current audio strips
Thanks for watching!
